Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Hurricane Harvey and Organizational Resilience

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project examines organizational processes associated with building stronger and more strategic communication networks to enhance the ability for organizations to adapt to significant changes wrought by disruptive events. The project is novel in its way to develop understanding of the characteristics of how organizations communicate and how information flows within and among organizations dealing with natural disasters. When communities experience disruptive events like natural disasters, the organizations that are part of the community also suffer. How do organizations recover in the short-term and long-term and what role does their recovery play in the community's recovery and resilience? While it seems obvious that organizations, such as businesses, civil organizations, and public agencies, would have a significant role, that role is not as well understood as it must be for the benefit of communities, organizations, and recovery efforts. The tendency is to focus on developing strategies for single organizations without sufficient consideration of the inter-organizational networks that are a pillar to the whole community. This work involves an innovative combination of qualitative interviews, participant observation, and social network analysis techniques to identify the key roles of brokers, isolates, and cliques in the immediate and long-term recovery of organizations within the community. The results will contribute to practical strategies for building organizational and community capacity in the aftermath of disruptive events. This work will also advance theory and method generally about interorganizational networks while developing the science of resilience using a network based approach.

Hurricane Harvey represented a significant and disruptive natural disaster that seriously affected business and community organizations around the Houston area. This project takes a network-based approach to understand organizational resilience against disruptive events, and how communication networks within and between organizations facilitate or hinder the immediate and long-term recovery from the disruptive event. Communicating through social networks and the way in which organizations are linked through their information sharing can inform national efforts to strengthen the ability of communities and organizations to function effectively in challenging circumstances. The project will use a mixed-method approach to characterize organizational communication characteristics. In particular, it will analyze existing organizational documents as one way to map out the basic social networks the organization employs to support information flows with key stakeholder groups. The research will then use in-situ observations and interviews with key organizational partners that make up stakeholder networks of impacted organizations to develop further understanding of resilience in terms of communication and network characteristics within and between organizations. Interviews with the stakeholders will also be used to determine the criterion of effective recovery. Network analysis will be conducted to link communication patterns with recovery outcomes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview and Project Objective

Field research was conducted in Houston and surrounding areas of Texas in the aftermath of Hurricane Harvey over the course of one year beginning in October of 2017. The project objective was to create new knowledge about how organizational capacity and partnerships with other organizations (“interorganizational networks”) support or undermine effective recovery from disruptive events. The project aimed to create an organizational communication framework regarding how planning and interorganizational networks impact the ability of the organization and their communities to rapidly recover from a disruption.

 

Scope of Work

This research advances the “science of resilience” by identifying internal work processes along with external interdependencies among organizations and their stakeholders that mutually impact each other. This project used social science methods including field research, nearly 100 in-depth interviews with workers and leaders representing over 60 nonprofit organizations and businesses. We also used workplace visits and observations, internal documents shared by participating organizations, website analysis, and news accounts to gain more complete information. This project’s analytical work includes multiple analysts coding these data to identify resilience strategies and how specific organizational communication actions cumulatively build up organizational resilience. Initial findings point to a progression of work functions that help organizations be more resilient as well as what “breaking points” cause organizations to flounder or have significant delays in their ability to return to normal functioning after the interruptions related to the storm.

 

Education

Working with undergraduate, master’s and doctoral students from social sciences (namely, communication and information science), the project has provided opportunities to teach about social science research and implications from using comprehensive mixed-method data. Students learned how to conduct research from a variety of experiences. Using an apprentice-based learning approach, they were actively involved in field trips to Houston and surrounding areas in Texas to (a) conduct site observations at organizations and professional meetings, (b) recruit and interview informants, and (c) gather secondary data such as documents, meeting agendas, meeting rosters, and calendars. Students were also involved in data management and analyses and continue to be involved in writing papers and developing associated products. This hands-on learning has benefited students in seeing how organizational communication theory and research designs apply to real-world contexts. It has been particularly beneficial in helping students see the complexity of real-world problems—just because one aspect of a problem is resolved, that correction may, in fact, generate new problems for organizations and their constituents.

 

Deliverables

At this time, accomplishments include academic products, professional talks, and educational impacts. Specifically, these include:

-          One publication about crisis communication and organizational resilience that is in press.

-          One publication that models necessary conditions that facilitate resilience is under review.

-          Seven talks have reached over 1,000 professionals in academia, human resources, and business leadership clubs. These talks have been delivered at various academic and professional meetings in Houston, TX; Miami, FL; Denver, CO; and New Jersey.

-          Outreach to a broad community of educators through the above and subsequent publications and talks. This outreach facilitates the integration of discoveries in undergraduate and graduate course content on organization studies, leadership, and research methods. As such, the findings contribute to the education of current and future generations of students who will become leaders in organizations faced with managing resilience. Findings provide such students with specific tools that can be readily applied in designing better organizational practices.

-          Publications from this project will inform future research about organizational and community resilience as an organizing and communication phenomenon. Such research will further refine models about the interdependence of bureaucratic and grass roots organizing after disaster, and issues associated with the future of work. As such, it will inform generations of leaders with new organizing and communicating skills that will be needed by professionals in the future.

 

Continuing Dividends of this Research

Ongoing work includes additional publications based on different analyses of this project’s data and a long-term project goal to transform the extensive qualitative data into quantifiable products that other scientists can use. Another aim of the project is to develop a website where papers, presentations, and data can be shared publicly. The website is live and will be populated with products as they come available (http://netsci.rutgers.edu/).  The data also expand a larger universe of data from two previous projects based on post-storm recovery including data gathered in a community located along the New Jersey shore that was impacted by Super-storm Sandy as well as data gathered in New Orleans following Hurricane Katrina (the New Orleans project was partially supported from NSF award #0554959). In sum, results from this research are leading to products that will better inform resilience planning, theory development, and applications by organizations and cross-sector coalitions.
